tasks.task: Sustainable farming practices on Hubmer Family Farm
subtasks: Participating in USDA Conservation Stewardship Program
Producing non-GMO crops
Feeding non-GMO crops to Berkshire hogs and free-range chickens
Adopting ridge tilling technique
Planting crops directly into standing residue
Reducing erosion and conserving moisture
Encouraging earthworm activity
Experimenting with ridge till yielding higher bean production
Using Orthman cultivator for weed control and hilling effect
Implementing strip till or banding fertilizer for efficiency
Planting cover crops (vetch and rye)
Recycling manure through livestock farming
Showing the evolution of the family farm over 92 years

tasks.task: Sustainable farming practices on Hubmer Family Farm
subtasks: Participating in USDA Conservation Stewardship Program (but maybe combine with other practices)

tasks.task: ridge tilling practices (planting and cultivating), livestock management (feeding and utilizing manure), and cover cropping. So those three MAINTASKs would cover most of their sustainable farming practices.
Sustainable farming practices on Hubmer Family Farm
Sustainable farming: Cover Crops and Manure Recycling

Given that the transcript mentions their path from selling pigs to market to direct marketing, which is more about the market, maybe not part of the physical tasks. But the "inside view of land stewardship" suggests that the focus is on the farming practices, so those three tasks I mentioned, plus ridge tilling and manure management, plus livestock management. So perhaps three MAINTASKs.
Integration of Cover Crops and Manure Recycling

Check if there's any other specific tasks not covered yet. The farmer mentioned, "We've added to it in the last 92 years," referring to the family farm. I don't think that's a task, but it's a comment on their history. Another part where they say, "No need to run a big 300 horsepower tractor to bury your residue," so maybe not. The interview is mostly about their practices, so the three MAINTASKs with their subtasks seem appropriate.

So I think the three tasks capture the essence of their sustainable farming practices as discussed in the video. Let me check if the transcript mentions anything else. Hmm, the interviewer mentions clips of the processing setup. Maybe butchering the meat, but since it's in the "Show us some of the crops outside," perhaps that's just part of the tour. So I think the tasks are focused on what's discussed, which are their farming and husbandry practices, hence the three MAINTASKs.
Sustainable farming practices on Hubmer Family Farm
subtasks: Participating in USDA Conservation Stewardship Program
Producing non-GMO crops
Feeding non-GMO crops to Berkshire hogs and free-range chickens
Using ridge tilling (planting into standing residue, using Orthman cultivator for weed control and hilling, applying fertilizer through strip till)
Planting cover crops (vetch and rye)
Recycling manure through direct marketing and crop rotation
